### Steps to reproduce

This should be a quick fix:

The error message tries to quote the given executable name when that executable cannot be found, but fails to do so:

```powershell
Switch-Process NoSuchExe
```

### Expected behavior

```console
Switch-Process: Command 'NoSuchExe' was not found. The specified command must be an executable.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Switch-Process: Command '' was not found. The specified command must be an executable.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-rc.1 on Unix-like platforms.
```

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Currently, if you run something like:

```console
PS /Users/steve/repos/PowerShell> ls -l *.md | select-string "(?<mode>.*?)\s+(?<hardlinks>[0-9]+)\s+(?<owner>\w+)\s+(?<group>\w+)\s+(?<size>[0-9]+)\s+(?<date>\w+\s[0-9]+\s[0-9:]+)\s+(?<filename>.+)"

-rw-r--r--  1 steve  staff   5122 Oct 24 08:37 ADOPTERS.md
-rw-r--r--  1 steve  staff  20383 Oct 27 09:33 README.md
```

`select-string` just highlights the matches (imagine the text above highlighted).  However, it would be useful to have a `-AsPSObject` switch so that if there are named groups, those becomes properties of an object instance:

```console
PS /Users/steve/repos/PowerShell> ls -l *.md | select-string "(?<mode>.*?)\s+(?<hardlinks>[0-9]+)\s+(?<owner>\w+)\s+(?<group>\w+)\s+(?<size>[0-9]+)\s+(?<date>\w+\s[0-9]+\s[0-9:]+)\s+(?<filename>.+)"

mode       hardlinks owner group size  date         filename
----       --------- ----- ----- ----  ----         --------
-rw-r--r-- 1         steve staff 20383 Oct 27 09:33 README.md
-rw-r--r-- 1         steve staff 20383 Oct 27 09:33 ADOPTERS.md
```


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Clearly not a common use case, but a bug nonetheless:

When you use `Switch-Process` (`exec`) to replace the current PowerShell process (running an interactive session) with a different shell's interactive session (e.g., `bash`), that session's command-line editing is broken.

```powershell
# Run on macOS or Linux
Switch-Process /bin/bash
```

### Expected behavior

A regular interactive Bash session.

### Actual behavior

What the user types on the Bash command line doesn't print (however, submitting commands and printing output works normally).

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-rc.1 on macOS 12.6 or Linux
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: Switch-Process, when used to replace the PowerShell process with an interactive (different) shell session, breaks that session

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

It is understood that the newly introduced, Unix-only `Switch-Process` cmdlet (alias `exec`) is _not_ designed to have full feature parity with the `exec` built-in in POSIX-compatible shells, notably not with respect to supporting stream redirections.

However, making the replacement process inherit the caller's environment is an important part of `exec` functionality (and it is how it works in POSIX-compatible shells).

Related discussion predating `Switch-Process`:
* #12750

```powershell
# Run on macOS or Linux.
# Note the use of `exec`; if you remove it, 'bar' prints as expected
pwsh -nop -c '$env:FOO=''bar''; exec /bin/sh -c ''echo $FOO'''
```

### Expected behavior

```console
bar
```


### Actual behavior

(no output)


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-rc.1 on Unix-like platforms
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: Switch-Process (exec) fails to make the replacement process inherit the calling process' environment variables

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Installed version is `PowerShell-7.3.0-rc.1-win-x64.msi`.

Enable the feature using PowerShell 7. You will notice it works:
```
PS C:\Windows> Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Hyper-V -All
Do you want to restart the computer to complete this operation now?
[Y] Yes  [N] No  [?] Help (default is "Y"):
```
Now try to disable it from same PowerShell, you will notice it does not work with either option:
```
PS C:\Windows> Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Hyper-V -All
Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature: A parameter cannot be found that matches parameter name 'All'.
PS C:\Windows> Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Offline -FeatureName Microsoft-Hyper-V -All
Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature: A parameter cannot be found that matches parameter name 'Offline'.
```

### Expected behavior

```console
`Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature` should undo all the changes made by `Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature` or at least the `Offline` feature should instead.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The Microsoft official website does not explain or link on how to undo the change, apparently it's only one-way:
[url=https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/virtualization/hyper-v-on-windows/]Hyper-V on Windows 10[/url]
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
$PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

# PR Summary

Fix #18375

Update `Out-Printer` to remove all decorating ANSI escape sequences added by PowerShell formatting before sending to printer. For pure string input, however, it keeps the string unchanged when sending to printer.

For `$PSVersionTable | Format-Table -Property * | Out-Printer -Name 'Microsoft Print to PDF'`, the printed text is:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/199123873-a75aa1ae-71e2-4957-8b6e-b171a7140876.png)

For `$PSStyle.Foreground.Red + "Hello" + $PSStyle.Reset | Out-Printer -Name 'Microsoft Print to PDF'`, the printed text is:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/199123950-cb696bcc-d09a-4deb-9076-4e5b1fb57dc8.png)

### Steps to reproduce

### Steps to reproduce

I want a single file, self contained executable.

Minimal example of the bug is [here](https://github.com/Kurren123/powershell-bug). Clone, restore and then publish. 

When I run the published console app on a windows machine I get an exception, see below.

### Expected behavior

```console
The console app runs (no output).
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

This is an inconsistency that has always existed, from what I can tell.
Resolving it would amount to a breaking change,
so the answer may be just to _document_ it.
Either way, it would be good to know if there is a by-design element to this inconsistency.

```powershell
# For the object without a .Prop property, returns a [pscustomobject] with a .Prop property that contains $null
[pscustomobject] @{ Prop=1 }, [pscustomobject] @{  } | Select-Object -Property Prop

'---'

# !! For the object without a .Prop property, emits a (non-terminating) ERROR, complaining that the 
# !! property doesn't exist.
[pscustomobject] @{ Prop=1 }, [pscustomobject] @{  } | Select-Object -ExpandProperty Prop
```


### Expected behavior

```console
Prop
----
   1
       # $null value
---
1
       # $null value
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Prop
----
   1

---
1
Select-Object:
Line |
   8 |  … Prop=1 }, [pscustomobject] @{  } | Select-Object -ExpandProperty Prop
     |                                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | Property "Prop" cannot be found.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-rc.1
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

According to the Powershell DSC documentation for 1.1, 2.0 and 3.0 preview
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/dsc/concepts/configurations?view=dsc-3.0

the following should be a valid configuration:

```
Configuration MyTest {
  Import-DscResource -ModuleName 'PSDscResources'  # With or without this line
  File TestDir {
    Type = 'Directory'; DestinationPath = 'C:\MyTest'; Ensure = 'Present'
  }
}
```

Both with and without the import-dsc resource, the configuration is accepted, but cannot be compiled with an error that suggests a fundamentally backwards incompatible change to how Powershell Core's DSC expects a configuration to work.


### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Configuration MyTest { File TestDir { Type='Directory'; DestinationPath='C:\MyTest'; Ensure='Present' } }
PS> Configuration
    Directory: C:\PS\MyTest


Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
-a----        10/28/2022  11:59 AM           1934 localhost.mof
WARNING: The configuration 'MyTest' is loading one or more built-in resources without explicitly importing associated modules. Add Import-DscResource –ModuleName 'PSDesiredStateConfiguration' to your configuration to avoid this message.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Configuration MyTest { File TestDir { Type='Directory'; DestinationPath='C:\MyTest'; Ensure='Present' } }
PS> Configuration
WARNING: Module PSDesiredStateConfiguration is loaded in Windows PowerShell using WinPSCompatSession remoting session; please note that all input and output of commands from this module will be deserialized objects. If you want to load this module into PowerShell please use 'Import-Module -SkipEditionCheck' syntax.
Configuration: Cannot process argument transformation on parameter 'ResourceModuleTuplesToImport'. Cannot convert the "System.Collections.ArrayList" value of type "System.Collections.ArrayList" to type "System.Tuple`3[System.String[],Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleSpecification[],System.Version]".
```

```console
type "System.Tuple`3[System.String[],Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleSpecification[],System.Version]". ---> System.Management.Automation.ArgumentTransformationMetadataException: Cannot convert the "System.Collections.ArrayList" value of type "System.Collections.ArrayList" to type
"System.Tuple`3[System.String[],Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleSpecification[],System.Version]". ---> System.Management.Automation.PSInvalidCastException: Cannot convert the "System.Collections.ArrayList" value of type "System.Collections.ArrayList" to type
"System.Tuple`3[System.String[],Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ModuleSpecification[],System.Version]".
                                     at System.Management.Automation.LanguagePrimitives.ThrowInvalidCastException(Object valueToConvert, Type resultType)
                                     at System.Management.Automation.LanguagePrimitives.ConvertNoConversion(Object valueToConvert, Type resultType, Boolean recurse, PSObject originalValueToConvert, IFormatProvider formatProvider, TypeTable backupTable)
                                     at System.Management.Automation.LanguagePrimitives.ConversionData`1.Invoke(Object valueToConvert, Type resultType, Boolean recurse, PSObject originalValueToConvert, IFormatProvider formatProvider, TypeTable backupTable)
```

title: PS 7.2

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

What date is wrong?

```powershell
 PS > & {
 >> $format = 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss'
 >> (Get-Date (stat -c %w /root) -f $format) + " # $(which stat) 'birth time'"
 >> (Get-Item /root).CreationTime.ToString($format) + " # CreationTime"
 >> (Get-Date (stat -c %y /root) -f $format) + " # $(which stat) 'last modified time'"
 >> (Get-Item /root).LastAccessTime.ToString($format) + " # LastAccessTime"
 >> (Get-Item /root).LastWriteTime.ToString($format) + " # LastWriteTime"  
 >> }
2021-03-10 22:31:43 # /usr/bin/stat 'birth time'
2022-06-04 23:48:49 # CreationTime
2022-06-04 23:48:49 # /usr/bin/stat 'last modified time'
2021-03-10 22:35:51 # LastAccessTime
2022-06-04 23:48:49 # LastWriteTime

```

### Expected behavior

```console
CreationTime must be equivalent to the native `stat` birth of file
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Creation time equivalent `stat` last modified time
```


### Error details

```console
No errors
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.7
OS                             Linux 6.0.5-arch1-1 #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Wed, 26 Oct 2022 15:25:45 +0000
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

title: Update the cgmanifest

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I understand that Microsoft no longer supports older versions of PowerShell.

Many of my modules try to accommodate older versions of PowerShell and while I no longer use v3 or v4 in prod, I would like to continue testing these versions and need a reliable source for WMF.

Considering that Microsoft provides various ways to redistribute Windows Updates including WSUS, SCCM, local repositories and even DVDs, I would like to create my own repository and add the older versions of WMF to a GitHub repo. This will ensure I have continued access to the files when performing tests and I will ensure that it is known that these are no longer officially supported by Microsoft.

I believe the licensing allows for this but wanted to ask permission from the team.

Thanks,
Chrissy

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I'd like to view the private working set of Task Manager.

At first do not start Task Manager.

Start powershell and type

`Get-Counter "\Process(taskmgr)\Working Set - Private"`

Press Enter, powershell shows

`Get-Counter: The \Process(taskmgr)\Working Set - Private performance counter path is not valid.`

This is ok because Task Manager is not running.

Then press `ctrl+alt+delete` and start Task Manager, and type again

`Get-Counter "\Process(taskmgr)\Working Set - Private"`

Press Enter, powershell shows

`Get-Counter: The \Process(taskmgr)\Working Set - Private performance counter path is not valid.`

Looks like powershell thinks Task Manager is not started.

P.S. If I start Task Manager first and then start powershell, there's no such issue.

### Expected behavior

```console
The private working set of Task Manager.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Get-Counter: The \Process(taskmgr)\Working Set performance counter path is not valid.
```


### Error details

```console
    Message : The \Process(taskmgr)\Working Set performance counter path is not valid.

    OffsetInLine     : 1

    Line             : Get-Counter "\Process(taskmgr)\Working Set"
    PositionMessage  : At line:1 char:1
                       + Get-Counter "\Process(taskmgr)\Working Set"
                       + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    InvocationName   : Get-Counter
    CommandOrigin    : Internal
ScriptStackTrace      : at <ScriptBlock>, <No file>: line 1
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When referencing a _regular_ variable with `$using:` its existence is _enforced_ (including when _scope_ specifiers such as `$script:` are used); that is, the non-existent of the referenced variable causes an error.

However, when _namespace variable notation_ is used, non-existence is quietly ignored and the references evaluates to `$null`

```powershell
# Error, due to referenced variable not existing 
Start-Job { $using:NOSUCHVARIABLE } | Receive-Job -Wait -AutoRemoveJob
Start-Job { $using:variable:NOSUCHVARIABLE } | Receive-Job -Wait -AutoRemoveJob  # variable: drive is special; no existence check for *other* drives' items

# Namespace variable notation (with a drive other than variable:)
# Quietly ignored, evaluates to $null
Start-Job { $using:env:NOSUCH } | Receive-Job -Wait -AutoRemoveJob       # drive exists, item doesn't
Start-Job { $using:NOSUCHDRIVE:foo } | Receive-Job -Wait -AutoRemoveJob  # drive doesn't exist.
```

### Expected behavior

All four commands should report an error similar to `Start-Job: The value of the using variable '...' cannot be retrieved because it has not been set in the local session.`


### Actual behavior

Only the first two commands emit such an error, the latter two quietly pass `$null` to the job script block.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-rc.1
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

The following parameter declarations don't make sense, and should ideally break during the parsing stage:

```powershell
& { param($env:HOME) $env:HOME } hi

& { param($script:foo) $foo } hi; $foo
```



### Expected behavior

Parsing should break with an error message that states that namespace variable notation / scoped variables aren't supported as parameters; only regular, unscoped variables may be used.

### Actual behavior

```console
/Users/jdoe
hi
hi
```

That is, the parameter and its argument were effectively ignored in the first case, and in the second case a script-scoped variable was actually created.


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-rc.1
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When you use `-ErrorVariable` and a _statement-terminating_ error is captured, it is unexpectedly captured as a `System.Exception`-derived type, not as a `System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord`, the way it is captured in the automatic `$Error` variable.

Note: While this inconsistency could selectively be used to infer whether a given error was non-terminating or statement-terminating, I suspect it isn't intentional; determining the error type should be an intentional feature: see:
 *  #4781

Repro:

```powershell
# Define a function that first reports a non-terminating error,
# and then a statement-terminating one.
function foo {

  [CmdletBinding()]
  param()

  # Report a NON-TERMINATING error.
  $PSCmdlet.WriteError(
    [System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord]::new(
      "non-terminating error", # message
      "test_nt", # custom error ID
      'NotSpecified', # [System.Management.Automation.ErrorCategory] value
      $null # target object
    )
  )

  'continuing...'

  # Report a STATEMENT-TERMINATING error, which aborts execution of the function.
  $PSCmdlet.ThrowTerminatingError(
    [System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord]::new(
      "statement-terminating error",
      "test_st",
      'NotSpecified',
      $null
    )
  )

  'Never get here.'

}

# Uses the foo function defined above.
# Note: If you additionally use -ErrorAction Stop, a similar discrepancy
#       occurs: $captured then contains a [System.Management.Automation.ActionPreferenceStopException] instance.
$Error.Clear(); foo -ErrorVariable captured

'-- $Error types:'
$Error | % GetType | % FullName

'-- -ErrorVariable types:'
$captured | % GetType | % FullName
```

### Expected behavior

```console
# ... error output
-- $Error types:
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
-- -ErrorVariable types:
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
```


### Actual behavior

```console
# ... error output
-- $Error types:
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
-- -ErrorVariable types:
System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord
System.Management.Automation.CmdletInvocationException
```

That is, `-ErrorVariable` captured the statement-terminating error as a `System.Management.Automation.CmdletInvocationException` instance rather than as a `System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord` instance.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.8
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: core PowerShell engine, interpreter, and runtime
labels.name: WG-Engine

labels.description: The issue is new and needs to be triaged by a work group.
labels.name: Needs-Triage

title: -ErrorVariable unexpectedly captures statement-terminating errors as instances of System.Exception-derived types rather than of ErrorRecord

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Currently, the `System.IComparable` interface is honored when `Sort-Object` compares two input objects.

It would be beneficial to also honor the `System.Collections.IStructuralComparable` interface for collection-like types that implement it, notably `[array]`s.

That is, the following should work as expected:

```powershell
# SHOULD be '[10 42]', '[9 42]', but currently isn't, because the input arrays are effectively
# *stringified* and then compared.
(9, 42), (10, 42) |  Sort-Object -Descending | ForEach-Object { "[$_]" }
```

Note that there are collection-like types that implement _both_ interfaces, in which case sorting  does work, notably `System.ValueTuple`:

```powershell
# OK ->  '[10 42]', '[9 42]'
(9, 42), (10, 42) |  Sort-Object -Descending { [ValueTuple]::Create.Invoke($_) }  | ForEach-Object { "[$_]" }
```


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Note that, more generally, the change to support `IStructuralComparable` should be made to whatever engine logic is at the heart of trivalent object comparisons, irrespective of a specific context such as `Sort-Object`  - perhaps [`PSObject.CompareTo()`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.management.automation.psobject.compareto)?

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.name: Up-for-Grabs

labels.name: WG-Cmdlets-Utility

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

The [parameters documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_functions_advanced_parameters?view=powershell-7.2) says that if a mandatory parameter is missing, the help message is shown as a prompt. (Various web sites imply this as well.)

> The `HelpMessage` argument specifies a string that contains a brief description of the parameter or its value. PowerShell displays this message in the prompt that appears when a mandatory parameter value is missing from a command.

I'm a PowerShell newbie, but "PowerShell displays this message in the prompt that appears when a mandatory parameter value is missing from a command" is pretty unambiguous. It says that 1) if there is a mandatory parameter, and 2) the value is missing, then 3) the specified help message will be displayed, and 4) that help message will be displayed at the prompt that appears asking for the missing value. I'm not sure how I could be misinterpreting that.

This is the example given in the official documentation, verbatim:

```powershell
Param(
    [Parameter(Mandatory,
    HelpMessage="Enter one or more computer names separated by commas.")]
    [string[]]
    $ComputerName
)
```


### Expected behavior

```console
PS> .\test-param-help-message.ps1

Enter one or more computer names separated by commas.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> .\test-param-help-message.ps1

cmdlet test-param.ps1 at command pipeline position 1
Supply values for the following parameters:
(Type !? for Help.)
ComputerName[0]:
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.name: Resolution-By Design

title: Use `Enum.HasFlags` part 1

body:
Since .NET Core 2.1, usage of `Enum.HasFlags` no longer has any performance impact, therefore bitwise flag comparison is not necessary.

For the sake of code readability, we should replace bitwise flag comparisons.

e.g. codegen: [sharplab](https://sharplab.io/#v2:).

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

## PR Summary

Increase timeout to make subsystem tests more reliable.

## PR Context

The `CommandPrediction` xUnit tests have been failing for the last 2 days because the expected operation cannot finish before the timeout. The expected operation is done via tasks using the thread pool. xUnit itself generates a lot of tasks backed by thread pool, which makes the task run unpredictable comparing with the real scenario. 

The old timeout has been working well until very recently (2 days ago), and it may be caused by changes in the CI agent or activities involved in the CI pipeline.

## PR Checklist

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Using the sample code provided at [Regex.MatchTimeout Property - Remarks](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.text.regularexpressions.regex.matchtimeout?view=net-6.0#remarks) to set REGEX_DEFAULT_MATCH_TIMEOUT in a console app results in the expected behavior. But when using the same code in a class library and invoking it from PowerShell 7.2.7, REGEX_DEFAULT_MATCH_TIMEOUT is set properly but the value is ignored by Regex operations.

Why is this happening?

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> .\ConsoleApp.exe

Default regex match timeout: 00:00:02
Regular expression pattern: [aeiouy]
Timeout interval for this regex: 2 seconds
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Import-Module .\ClassLibrary.dll; [ClassLibrary.Timeout]::SetRegexTimeout()

Default regex match timeout: 00:00:02
Regular expression pattern: [aeiouy]
Timeout interval for this regex: -0.001 seconds
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

`Out-Printer` outputs ANSI control characters even if operating system does not support them and even if you disable it by modifying `$PSStyle` variable: `$PSStyle.OutputRendering = [System.Management.Automation.OutputRendering]::PlainText`

To reproduce, execute following commands:

```powershell
# Print using the default printer
$PSVersionTable | Format-Table -Property * | Out-Printer

# or print to a XPS document (if you don't have a printer)
$PSVersionTable | Format-Table -Property * | Out-Printer -Name 'Microsoft XPS Document Writer'
```

### Expected behavior

```console
Name                      Key                       Value
----                      ---                       -----
PSVersion                 PSVersion                 7.2.7
PSEdition                 PSEdition                 Core
GitCommitId               GitCommitId               7.2.7
OS                        OS                        Microsoft Windows 6.3.9600
Platform                  Platform                  Win32NT
```


### Actual behavior

```console
[32;1mName                      Key                       Value[0m
[32;1m----                      ---                       -----[0m
PSVersion                 PSVersion                 7.2.7
PSEdition                 PSEdition                 Core
GitCommitId               GitCommitId               7.2.7
OS                        OS                        Microsoft Windows 6.3.9600
Platform                  Platform                  Win32NT
```


### Error details

```console
# There is no error
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 6.3.9600
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

I can reproduce this issue on Windows 10 and Windows 8.1

### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/732366/197805838-21c4d453-59eb-4fd8-9b07-493104716206.png)

Corrects incorrect cmdlet name in script, which has been causing for instance "Restart-Computer -Computername otherserver -Wait -For Powershell" to never complete.
Also fixes "Restart-Computer -ComputerName $_ -Force -Wait -Timeout 1800" where powershell is implicit.

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

## PR Context

Resolves #12232
Also resolves  #11002 which is also dependant on this powershell script, and it hangs in the same place.
Issue is that the powershell script invoked has an exception because of the incorrect cmdlet-name, and this exception is silently ignored, so it never determines that any powershell is reachable on restarted servers.

```console
$str = '🦄❤️🌈阳山伟伟'

	$count++
	Start-Sleep -Milliseconds 10
}
```

title: Bump Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.NetAnalyzers from 7.0.0-preview1.22521.1 to 7.0.0-preview1.22524.2

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I have a little .NET app (targeting .NET 6/7), and I want to measure how long it takes to launch it. The app automatically closes itself upon launch and reports the elapsed time. The time reported by `Measure-Command` cmdlet and inconsistent with the time reported by the app.

When I ran the cmdlet I get these results from the cmdlet:
```ps
PS throwaway\winforms-nativeaot> Measure-Command { .\bin\Release\net6.0-windows\winforms-nativeaot.exe }

Days              : 0
Hours             : 0
Minutes           : 0
Seconds           : 0
Milliseconds      : 88
Ticks             : 881686
TotalDays         : 1.02046990740741E-06
TotalHours        : 2.44912777777778E-05
TotalMinutes      : 0.00146947666666667
TotalSeconds      : 0.0881686
TotalMilliseconds : 88.1686
```

DebugViewer report the data from the app:
```
[28008] winforms_nativeaot: time taken: 146.5512 ms || 1465512 ticks // 146 ms 
```

When I ran a comparable command from bash, I get these results:
```
$ time ./bin/Release/net6.0-windows/winforms-nativeaot.exe

real    0m0.266s
user    0m0.000s
sys     0m0.000s
```

And I also tried the good ol' cmd:
```
D:\Development\throwaway\winforms-nativeaot>cmd /v:on /c "echo !TIME! & .\bin\Release\net6.0-windows\winforms-nativeaot.exe & echo !TIME!"         
14:33:16.35 
14:33:16.59
```

App | PowerShell 5.1 | PowerShell 7.2 | Bash | Cmd
--|--|--|--|--
146 ms | 34.337 | 88.1686 | 266 | 240

It's clear that PowerShell reports grossly incorrect results as it can't take less time than the actual app. Bash reports the correct time as there's some overhead to launch the app before it gets to the `Main` entrypoint.

To verify, I have also run this, and results are surprising to say the least:
```ps
 Measure-Command { timeout 3 }

Days              : 0
Hours             : 0
Minutes           : 0
Seconds           : 2
Milliseconds      : 322
Ticks             : 23221427
TotalDays         : 2.68766516203704E-05
TotalHours        : 0.000645039638888889
TotalMinutes      : 0.0387023783333333
TotalSeconds      : 2.3221427
TotalMilliseconds : 2322.1427
```



<details>
<summary>.NET app code</summary>



```cs
using System.Diagnostics;

namespace winforms_nativeaot;

static class Program
{
    [STAThread]
    static void Main()
    {
        Stopwatch stopwatch = Stopwatch.StartNew();

        // To customize application configuration such as set high DPI settings or default font,
        // see https://aka.ms/applicationconfiguration.
        ApplicationConfiguration.Initialize();

        Application.ApplicationExit += (s, e) =>
        {
            stopwatch.Stop();
            Trace.WriteLine($"winforms_nativeaot: time taken: {stopwatch.Elapsed.TotalMilliseconds} ms || {stopwatch.ElapsedTicks} ticks // {stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds} ms");
        };

        Application.Run(new Form1());
    }    
}

public partial class Form1 : Form
{
    public Form1()
    {
        this.Activated += (_, __) => Application.Exit();
    }
}
```



</details>

### Expected behavior

```console
The reported time is correct, at least within the same order of magnitude.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The reported time is grossly inaccurate.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.22621.608
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.22621.608
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0

SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

----

----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22621
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

The pre-v7.3 experimental `PSNativeCommandErrorActionPreference` feature allows setting the new `$PSNativeCommandUseErrorActionPreference` preference variable to `$true`, so that any call to an external (native) program that results in a nonzero exit code emits a PowerShell error (in addition to any preceding stderr output emitted by the external program itself).

For this error to be most useful, it should be a _statement-terminating_ error - i.e. one that can be caught with `try` / `catch`, whereas it currently is a _non-terminating_ error.

Note that the concept of a _non-terminating_ error is a PowerShell-specific one, and doesn't really apply to external programs.

```powershell
$PSNativeCommandUseErrorActionPreference = $true

try {
  # Call an external program that reports a nonzero exit code.
  & ($IsWindows ? 'cmd' : 'sh') ($IsWindows ? '/c' : '-c') 'exit 1'
}
catch {
  'caught!'
}
'after'
```


### Expected behavior

```console
caught!
after
```


### Actual behavior

```console
NativeCommandExitException: Program "sh" ended with non-zero exit code: 1.
after
```

That is, the unexpectedly _non_-terminating error wasn't caught.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.8
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: The issue is new and needs to be triaged by a work group.
labels.name: Needs-Triage

title: Native error handling: `$PSNativeCommandUseErrorActionPreference = $true` unexpectedly causes non-terminating, not statement-terminating errors

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a CNAME DNS entry that points to an authorized DHCP server.
2. Run Get-DhcpServerInDC.

### Expected behavior

```console
Expected behavior is for Get-DhcpServerInDC to return only authorized DHCP server listed in the "CN=NetServices,CN=Services,CN=Configuration,DC=DOMAIN" configuration of Active Directory.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Get-DhcpServerInDC is returning objects that include a DNS alias for one of the authorized DHCP servers.
```


### Error details

```console
This causes errors when the objects are piped as the DNS Alias typically is not an Active Directory Computer Object and therefor generates errors in the pipeline.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

This is the results of Get-DhcpServerInDC (with a select to limit results to the server entries in question)
![Returns](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/100967931/197600002-cf70e417-f928-4d71-a4a4-0d60a5ca0756.png)
Note that the top entry is the Alias from DNS. The bottom entry is the actual server.

This is shows that only the actual server is listed in Active Directory
![ADSI Edit Results](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/100967931/197602043-abdfaf60-93ef-4913-8674-949cda83579b.png)

Attempting to use "Remove-DhcpServerInDC" for the erroneous entry results in this error.
![Remove Error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/100967931/197601770-aadcda67-3856-4908-bc55-ac066a683bc0.png)

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

### Steps to reproduce

Doubt if it's a bug, limitation or a lack of enough knowledge:
I'm loading arbitrary .NET assemblies (which I have no control of their source code) and invoke them.
A lot of them are using `console.writeline` (or similar functions), and I want to capture it, means redirecting it to a Powershell variable or even to a file, but nothing seems to catch this - it's just printing it to the console.
Tried about million ways to overcome this unsuccessfully (> file.txt , out-string, out-variable, and so on...)
here is the code:

```
$file = "path\to\my\compiled\assembly"
$bytes = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes($file)
$assembly = [Reflection.Assembly]::Load($bytes)
$params = @(,[String[]]@("some params"))
$assembly.EntryPoint.invoke($null, $params)  # <-- I want to catch this output, into a variable or a file, but it keeps be printed to the screen.
```


### Expected behavior

```console
PS> $x = $assembly.EntryPoint.invoke($null, $params) | out-string
PS> $x
output
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> $x = $assembly.EntryPoint.invoke($null, $params) | out-string
PS> $x
nothing
```

### Steps to reproduce

```
Open Windows Terminal. 
PowerShell 7.2.6
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation.

https://aka.ms/powershell
Type 'help' to get help.

   A new PowerShell stable release is available: v7.2.7
   Upgrade now, or check out the release page at:
     https://aka.ms/PowerShell-Release?tag=v7.2.7

PS
```

Run "Check for Updates" in Microsoft Update

### Expected behavior

```console
PowerShell updates automatically to 7.2.7
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Powershell is not updated
```

# PR Summary
In #15543 it was discovered that if you have a case where a script is named in a way that can be interpreted as hexadecimal (such as `0x.ps1` and you execute it without the dot backslash convention (`.\0x.ps1` the script will always return null.
@vexx32 identified the problem as being an oversight in an `if` statement that doesn't account for a number appended a few lines above.

## PR Context

<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

## PR Summary

The `Regex.IsMatch` in `GetDotNetType` is pretty expensive. Actually, in most cases, we can use simpler checks to get what we need. Handle those common cases so as to avoid regular expression checks when possible.

## PR Context

It's reported from MS internal team the `GetDotNetType` method call results in tons of regular expression creations, taking up a lot of CPU usage.

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

body: ### Summary of the new feature / enhancement The output of Get-ChildItem is VERY wide. Especially on Unix. There are so much space between the username and the group name. Most times the standard width of a terminal window on Linux isn't width enough. On Windows are only four rows (Mode, LastWriteTime, Length and Name) instead of the six on Unix (UnixMode, User, Group, LastWriteTime, Size and Name), so it haven't so much effect. But it is also more width then needed. Btw: Why is the same column with the same thing on Unix called "Size" and on Windows called "Length" ? ### Proposed technical implementation details (optional) _No response_

body:
Remove the following unsupported versions from `$PSVersionTable.PSCompatibleVersions`:

| Version | End-of-support
| -- | -- |
| 5.0 | October 10, 2017* |
| 6.0 | February 13, 2019 |
| 6.1 | September 28, 2019 |
| 6.2 | September 4, 2020 |
| 7.1 | May 8, 2022 |

The following versions were **not** removed as they are apparently still supported by Microsoft:

| Version | |
| -- | -- |
| 1.0  | Optional component of Windows Server 2008, which is supported under Extended Security Updates on Azure until January 9, 2024. |
| 2.0 | Integrated in Windows Server 2008 R2, which is supported under Extended Security Updates on Azure until January 9, 2024. |

*Installed by default on Windows 10 version 1511, which is out-of-support since October 10, 2017. See [Windows PowerShell System Requirements](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/windows-powershell/install/windows-powershell-system-requirements#windows-powershell-50).

### Prerequisites

### Steps to reproduce

I installed Powershell through the Microsoft Store and when I start Powershell I get an update notification.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7734808/197207608-a496dc22-b561-4e4c-9fec-50ad04037550.png)

However the Microsoft Store app is not up to date so I can't update.

### Expected behavior

```console
Since I installed the app through Microsoft Store don't prompt for update if the Microsoft Store's version is not actually updated.

Otherwise, provide a guide on how to update manually, I can see that pwsh.exe is installed, in my case, at `C:\Users\David\AppData\Local\Microsoft\WindowsApps\Microsoft.PowerShell_8wekyb3d8bbwe\pwsh.exe` however the `PowerShell-7.2.7-win-x86.zip` I downlaoded from the releases page contains many more files.

Do I actually need them all or just copying pwsh.exe will suffice?
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Prompting to update with a link to `https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v7.2.7`
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.6
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.6
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22621
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

facing issue in version: Powershell version powershell-7.2 and on powershell-7.1.3
OS: centos 7
module used : ExchangeOnlineManagement
Issue: I connected o365 via powershell using application. I connected succesfully. I tried to fetch any connector exists or not. 
That gets failed. But "$?" was not set to False. It always remains True. Earlier it was set to False in such a case.
Same issue I faced when I create any connector. IF connector creations fails, "$?" remains True instead of False.

In below code sample: 
1. connector1 does not exist in my o365 exchange. 
2. "myrule" as not created as account has reached limit to no. of rules already.

code sample:
$EncPassword = ConvertTo-SecureString -String 'passowd' -AsPlainText -Force 
Connect-ExchangeOnline -AppId 'appid of mine' -CertificateFilePath '/home/cert.pfx' -CertificatePassword $EncPassword -Organization 'myorgdomain.onmicrosoft.com'
 write-host "connected"
 Get-InboundConnector 'connector1' 
if ($? -eq $True) 
{ 
    write-host "inbound connector exist"
  }
  else
{
   write-host "inbound connector does not exist"
}
     try 
    {
      New-TransportRule -Name 'myrule' -FromScope NotInOrganization -SentToScope InOrganization  -Enabled $true  -Priority 0 -SetSCL -1
       if ($? -eq $True)
        {
         write-host "inbound rule created"
         } 
        else
         {
              write-host "inbound rule creation failed"
         }
       } 
       catch 
       { write-error "This is exception" }

### Expected behavior

```console
$? should be set to $False as both commands were actually failed. It was working before few days but suddenly behaviour looks changed.

Expected output:
connected
inbound connector does not exist
inbound rule creation failed
```


### Actual behavior

```console
$? always set to $True even both commands were actually failed. It was working before few days but suddenly behaviour looks changed.

actual output:
connected
inbound connector exist
inbound rule created
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
actual output:
connected
inbound connector exist
inbound rule created
```


### Visuals

_No response_

In `PowerShell-CI-linux`: https://dev.azure.com/powershell/PowerShell/_build/results?buildId=111689&view=logs&j=8579d1dd-da9d-5760-afc4-fb4c05cf5d6d&t=236f801b-8fac-50c5-f817-425a182daa54&l=6000

```log
/home/vsts/work/1/s/test/tools/NamedPipeConnection/src/code/NamedPipeConnection.cs(61,13): warning CA1816: NamedPipeClient.Dispose() calls GC.SuppressFinalize(object), a method that is typically only called within an implementation of 'IDisposable.Dispose'. Refer to the IDisposable pattern for more information. [/home/vsts/work/1/s/test/tools/NamedPipeConnection/src/code/Microsoft.PowerShell.NamedPipeConnection.csproj::TargetFramework=net7.0]
```

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

This may be a windows problem. But I need your help to figure it out and can't reproduce on Windows Powershell

Just run: 
```
$c = Get-credential
Start-Process cmd -Credential $c
```
or one liner `Start-Process cmd -Credential $get-credential``
(I am using credentials of a local user from my machine. Not domain-joined.)


### Expected behavior

```console
A new window opens, I can write several lines in the new window, running as another user.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
A new window opens, I can write one line and press enter. Then the input on that window HANGS. Keypresses are not handled anymore.

If I switch focus back to the parent window, the input missing input is processed. If you keep playing, the input on the parent caller window may hang its processing too.
```


### Error details

```console
n/a
```


### Environment data

```powershell
-> Windows 11 Pro 21H2 22000.1098
-> Fails using Pwsh 7.2.6, unable to reproduce on Windows Powershell
-> Can reproduce with both legacy ConHost.exe or Windows Terminal Preview (1.16.2642.0)
-> Also happens on a second computer.

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.6
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.6
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3901474/196816752-1bd7a2ba-ee48-49d4-9740-5f7df94bd327.png)

The second line, marked by the arrow, does not appear until you switch focus back and forth between both windows.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms
[Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds

### Expected behavior

```console
Should give you your true screen resolution
e.g. a 1080p screen should always return
Size     : {Width=1920, Height=1080}
```


### Actual behavior

```console
If the screen uses scaling an incorrect resolution is returned
e.g. a 1080p screen with 125% scaling returns
Size     : {Width=1536, Height=864}
```


### Error details

```console
This happens if in the app.manifest 
"dpiawareness" is not set to"permonitorv2".
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/sbscs/application-manifests#dpiawareness

The same applies to
[System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::PrimaryMonitorSize

As a workaround can be used:
Get-CimInstance -Class Win32_DesktopMonitor | Select-Object ScreenWidth,ScreenHeight
This provides the correct resolution
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.6
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.6
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

    - [ ] [Make sure you've added a new test if existing tests do not effectively test the code changed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#before-submitting)
- **Tooling**
    - [ ] I have considered the user experience from a tooling perspective and don't believe tooling will be impacted.
    - **OR**
    - [ ] I have considered the user experience from a tooling perspective and opened an issue in the relevant tool repository. This may include:
        - [ ] Impact on [PowerShell Editor Services](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShellEditorServices) which is used in the [PowerShell extension](https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell) for VSCode
        (which runs in a different PS Host).
            - [ ] Issue filed: <!-- Number/link of that issue here -->
        - [ ] Impact on Completions (both in the console and in editors) - one of PowerShell's most powerful features.
            - [ ] Issue filed: <!-- Number/link of that issue here -->
        - [ ] Impact on [PSScriptAnalyzer](https://github.com/PowerShell/PSScriptAnalyzer) (which provides linting & formatting in the editor extensions).
            - [ ] Issue filed: <!-- Number/link of that issue here -->
        - [ ] Impact on [EditorSyntax](https://github.com/PowerShell/EditorSyntax) (which provides syntax highlighting with in VSCode, GitHub, and many other editors).
